data.sampled:
Covered call: The investor is selling a call option and simultaneously buying a corresponding call option, with the same strike price and expiration date. In this case, the investor is selling a $85 strike price call and buying a $92 strike price call.

Protective put: The investor is buying a put option and simultaneously selling a put option, with the same strike price and expiration date. In this case, the investor is buying a $80 strike price put and selling a $85 strike price put.

Simply put, the investor is creating a combination of options positions that will pay off if the underlying stock price stays below $85, while also providing some protection in case the stock price rises above $92.

data.sampled:
The option strategy being implemented is:

Selling a $390 strike price put option at $7.86 and buying a $385 strike price put option at $6.1 is a hedge.

The investor is selling protection against a potential decline in the price of the underlying stock (in this case, $390) while simultaneously buying protection against a potential decline in the price of the underlying stock that is less than $390 (in this case, $385). This is a hedging strategy that seeks to protect against losses in the underlying stock.

Selling a $390 strike price call option at $9.03 and buying a $395 strike price call option at $6.2 is also a hedge.

The investor is selling the right to buy the underlying stock at $390 at $9.03, while simultaneously buying the right to sell the underlying stock at $395 at $6.2. This is also a hedging strategy that seeks to protect against gains in the price of the underlying stock.
